headline: PULLOUT DEADLINE VOTED BY SENATE
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30—The Senate, reaffirming its past support of a deadline for ending the Vietnam war, went on record today in favor of the total withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina in six months, provided American prisoners of war were released.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Prepackaged Hospitals Urged for Use of Poor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Sept. 30—Senator George McGovern urged today that some of the 2,500 prepackaged hospitals that the Government keeps in storage for disaster relief be converted into community health centers for the urban and rural poor.

headline: News Analysis
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30—President Nguyen Van Thieu, who concluded his campain for re‐election tonight, can now step back and await what he undoubtedly will regard as a public mandate to govern for another four years.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Soldier Repays Stranger for '67 Favor
lead_paragraph: MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 30—While serving with the Army in 1967 in Vietnam, Michael Delaney saved the life of a wounded American soldier he had never seen by talking to the man for 16 hours by radio, to keep him from sinking into a coma. In a courtroom here today, Army Sgt. James P. Dempsey repaid Mr. Delaney by pledging his stripes to salvage Mr. Delaney's future.

headline: OFFICER DISCOUNTED REPORTS ON MYLAI
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Sept. 30 —A former intelligence officer who worked for Col. Oran K. Henderson said today that while in Vietnam he considered reports of civilian slayings at Mylai 4 to be “Vietcong propaganda.”

headline: U.S. COMBAT DEATHS PUT AT 29 FOR WEEK
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Sept. 30 (AP)—The United States command announced today that 29 Americans were killed in action in Indochina last week. It was the first time in 11 weeks that United States combat deaths exceeded 20.

headline: Urgent Call for Peace
lead_paragraph: The 57‐to‐38 majority by which the Senate has once again passed Senator Mansfield's amendment for withdrawal of all United States forces from Indochina within six months—a cutdown from the original time limit of nine months—reflects spreading national disillusionment with President Nixon's Vietnamization policy. The vote is an impressive demonstration of the determination in Congress to reassert legislative authority, if necessary, to bring the war to the early end the President has promised but not delivered.

headline: Ky, Addressing Anti ‐ Thieu Rally, Urges Vote Boycott
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Friday, Oct. I—Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky addressed a last‐minute political opposition meeting behind a barricade of Government policemen today and urged the voters to boycott this Sunday's elections, in which President Nguyen Van Thieu is the only candidate.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: 6 Antiwar Sailors Given Refugein Catholic Church
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Sept. 30 (AP) —Six sailors who are opposed to the war were given refuge in a Roman Catholic church today as their ship, the aircraft carrier Constellation, prepared to return to Vietnam.

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Foe Attacks 2 Camps Near Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30—The Saigon command said today that Communist forces attacked two South Vietnamese base camps along the Cambodian border northwest of here yesterday.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: PODGORNY LEAVES ON TRIP TO HANOI
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Sept. 30—President Nikolai V. Podgorny left here today for Hanoi at the head of a high‐ranking economic and military delegation in what was viewed as an attempt to court North Vietnam's favor after similar effort by Peking.
author: By Theodore Shabad Special to The New York Times

headline: Uncontested Saigon Election Is Assailed at Paris Talks
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Sept. 30 (Reuters)—The uncontested South Vietnamese presidential election Sunday came in for some harsh words from Hanoi and the Vietcong today as the stalled Paris peace talks resumed after two‐week break.

headline: COLONEL'S LAWYERS OBJECT TO WITNESS
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 1—The court‐martial of Col. Oran K. Henderson was conducted out of the presence of the jury today to allow for argument and testimony on a defense motion to prevent a key witness from appearing.

headline: Enemy Again Attacks Base in Cambodial
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2 (AP)—Despite a nightlong pounding by allied aircraft, North Vietnamese troops were reported to have launched another ground attack early today against a South Vietnamese artillery base in eastern Cambodia.

headline: POMPIDOU SCORES U.S. IN GREETING CHINESE
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 1 — President Pompidou had the nine members of a Chinese delegation in for lunch at the Elysde Palace today and took the occasion to criticize the presidential election in South Vietnam Sunday and the American bombing of North Vietnam.

headline: Hanging Up on War
lead_paragraph: WEEHAWKEN, N. J.—Richard Mozdiak of the Internal Revenue Service telephoned me recently and offered me a last chance to pay three telephone tax bills from last year. No I said, won't pay—not while the Government uses my money for its illegal, immoral, inhumane and purposeless war in Indochina.
author: By Kennett Love

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Experts Hail Army's Program For Drug Addicts in Vietnam
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 — A team of six experts on rehabilitation of drug addicts returned from two weeks in Vietnam today with the message that the Army was doing first‐class job of treating soldiers involved with drugs. The team called the soldiers chances of recovery excellent.
author: By Dana Adams Schmidt Special to The New York Times

headline: 9 Ashore as Carrier Sails; Navy Calls Them Deserters
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 1 (AP)—Nine young crewmen of the Constellation stayed inside a Roman Catholic church as the attack carrier sailed on schedule today for Vietnam. They were then declared deserters by the Navy.

headline: The Talk of Saigon
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1—The crowd of about a thousand pushed its way into the old French opera house across the street from the United States Embassy in what seemed at first to be a gathering of political figures to mark the end of the presidential election campaign. As it turned out, the one‐man candidacy of President Nguyen Van Thieu and the voting this Sun day were far from the thoughts of the Vietnamese in the Thong Nhut Theater, with its 14 swirling overhead fans. They were attending the weekly drawing of the national lottery and the number that emerged, 124916, brought someone somewhere 4 million piasters, or the equivalent of about $15.000.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Buddhist Anti‐Thieu Rally Is Attacked by the Police
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 2—South Vietnamese riot policemen made a tear‐gas attack last night on a Buddhist rally of about 300 people who were protesting tomorrow's uncontested presidential election.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: Two Youths Arrested
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 1 (AP)—Two youths were arrested at the An Quang Pagoda today, one with a firebomb in his hand. The latter was beaten by the police and taken away in a jeep.

headline: Ellsberg Friend, Held 47 Days, Agrees to Testify and Is Freed
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 — Anthony J. Russo, who has been imprisoned for 47 days for refusing to testify before a Federal grand jury investigating the Pentagon papers case, agreed today to appear and was set free.
author: By Steven V. Roberts Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. ENCOURAGED BY SOVIET TALKS
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2—The Nixon Administration has emerged from its latest round of discussions with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, persuaded that its relations with Moscow are better now than at any time in the last three years.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: ‘We Have to Choose Least of the Bad,’ Professor Says
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2—Prof. Nguyen Ngoc Huy, who intends to cast his Vote for President Nguyen Van Thieu in the one ‐ man election tomorrow, knows that opponents of the Government have sonic legitimate complaints. But he insists that President Thieu, though he is the only choice is a good choice.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: U.S. Court Orders Refund Of War Protesters' Bond
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) —The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ordered the District to refund collateral forfeited by many of the 12,000 persons arrested during the Mayday antiwar demonstrations.

headline: Industrialist Who Financed Medina's Defense Heads Diversified Business Empire Built in Five Years
lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla., Oct. 2—The career of Glenn W. Turner, the man who financed the defense in the court‐martial of Capt. Ernest L. Medina, hardly fits me pattern of ordinary industrialists.
author: By Martin Waldron Special to The New York Times

headline: Dear President Nixon, The last 24 hours has again been another day of pure hell for Americans in prison camps, cells ' cages in Southeast Asia
lead_paragraph: THE Air Force sends regular newsletters to the families of all the men it lists as captured by this country's enemies in Southeast Asia or missing in action there. Usually these communications are appropriately solemn, but sometimes they fall into a chatty, upbeat tone as they describe for the relatives the grassroots campaign—involving the writing of letters and sending petitions to Hanoi—that Legionnaires, Jaycees, church women and highschool students have undertaken on behalf of their husbands, sons and brothers. Most of this huge outpouring (amounting now to more than 50 million letters) has never reached Hanoi, and there is scant reason to suppose that Vietnamese officials able to read letters in English from Salinas, Kan., or Sante Fe, N.M., bother to do so. Yet such students of Vietnamese psychology as the Dallas multimultimillionaire H. Ross Perot have promised that “making the treatment of our men a visible issue in the United States will bring the North Vietnamese to their knees.” Vietnament Communists, Perot has discovered, suffer from an “inferiority complex” that leads them to crave.
author: By Joseph Lelyveld

headline: MILLIONS VOTING IN ONE‐MAN RACE IN SOUTH VIETNAM
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sun. day, Oct. 3—Millions of South Vietnamese are voting today to re‐elect Prsident Nguyen Van Thicu, the only candidate in an election that has brought embarrasment to American officials and distress to many Vietnamese.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Mother With Sons Injured in the War Has Burned Her Voting Card
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 2—A Buddhist housewife who has seen her five sons go to war expressed her anger and disgust with the Saigon Government by burning her yellow voting card last week. It was a small demonstration—one in a series that was started here two weeks ago by housewives, students and disabled veterans—and it went unnoticed by the rest of the city.

headline: Will the Real Majority Stand Up for Scoop Jackson?
lead_paragraph: ONE day in the early spring of 1969, a high‐ranking aide to President Nixon and a trusted friend from Capitol Hill sat talking in a West Wing office in the White House. The aide lowered his voice and spoke, as politicians say, “within the family.” The President's proposed Safeguard ABM system, the subject of this strategy meeting, was in trouble in the Senate, he said. Beyond that, he foresaw no end of trouble on a wide range of defense and foreign‐policy issues, especially the Vietnam war. Soon, he said, it would be Nixon's War.
author: By Richard J. Whalen

headline: The Freedom to Speak
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON—One of the historical lessons that the American people seem always to have difficulty learning is the truth of the warning enunciated so long ago: “Eternal vigilance is the price of liberty.” We can never rest on the laurels won by our ancestors, nor can we delude ourselves into thinking that our liberties, once having neen obtained, are forever secure.
author: By Sam J. Ervin Jr

headline: Students Cheering McGovern Pledge Of Draft Amnesty
lead_paragraph: BLACK RIVER FALLS, Wis., Oct. 2—Senator George McGovern is pledging that if elected President he will grant a general amnesty to draft evaders, including the thousands of young men who have exiled themselves abroad rather than serve in Vietnam.
author: By Christopher Lydon Special to The New York Times

headline: The Nation
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Self‐determination day in Saigon, once a pivotal date in President Nixon's withdrawal plan, comes now as just another long Sunday in the Vietnam agony. Around the White House, they smiled a little at the sick jokes of satirists of President Thieu's strenuous one‐man campaign against nay‐saying ballot‐rippers. President Nixon choked a little when he tried to pass off the exercise as at least better than Hanoi's kind of election.
author: — Max Frankel

headline: ROGERS EXPRESSES CONCERN ON MOVES REPORTED IN CHINA Says Administration Hopes Nixon's Trip to Peking Won't Be Affected
lead_paragraph: In the first official expression of the Administration's concern over events in China. Secretary of State William P. Rogers said yesterday that the United States hoped they would not affect President Nixon's plans to visit Peking.
author: By Tad Szulc

headline: Protests in Danang
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 3 (AP)—In Danang. South Vietnam's second largest city, Buddhist monks and youths, students and veterans threw stones and firebombs and blocked intersections near at least nine major polling stations. They made it virtually impossible for voters to get in.

headline: ENEMY STEPS UP SHELLING ATTACKS
lead_paragraph: SAIGON. South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 3 (AP)—Enemy forces reportedly doubled their shelling attacks across South Vietnam overnight and fired three rockets into Saigon early today, just a few hours before the polls opened for the presidential election.

headline: CARRIER DEPARTS AMID PROTESTERS
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO, Oct. 2 — When the aircraft carrier Constellation, which has been the target of antiwar demonstrators for six months, sailed for Vietnam yesterday, the military security was the tightest witnessed around this Navy base since World War II.

headline: P.O.W. Arithmetic
lead_paragraph: The campaign to free American P.O.W.'s has been clouded by confusion about their numbers. President Nixon this year spoke of “1,600 Americans in North Vietnam's jails.” In fact, it will be a stroke of good fortune if even half the 1,623 Americans listed ty the Defense Department as captured or missing in action prove to be alive.
author: — J.l

headline: To Waiting Wives' Of Officers the War Is One More Job
lead_paragraph: NEWBURGH, N. Y. —“We look at It not as ‘The War’ but as our husbands' job—right, girls?” Mrs. Michael M. Quinlan of Poughkeepsie, whose husband is an Army major in Quangnai, South Vietnam, won quick nods assent from the other officers' wives seated around her.
author: By Ralph Blumenthal Special to The New York Times

headline: Balloting Choice in Vietnam Was Thieu or Trash Can
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 3 — South Vietnam's presidential ref erendurn today was a duty, a chore, or an incomprehensible and perhaps ominous ritual, depending on whom you tallied to in the country's cities, villages and hamlets.

headline: ARMY REVIEWING CASE OF COLONEL
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) — Prodded by Congress, Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehike is personally reviewing Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert's file to determine whether the officer, who is now facing forced retirement, was unjustly relieved of his command.

headline: SAIGON REPORTS THIEU CAPTURING 90% OF THE VOTES
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Oct. 4 — President Nguyen Van Thieu won a new four‐year term yesterday in a one‐candidate election marked by scattered protests, terrorism, intensified enemy shelling and the largest reported voter turnout in recent Vietnamese history.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: Podgorny Greeted By Hanoi Turnout; Press Hails Soviet
lead_paragraph: HANOI, North Vietnam, Oct. 3 (Agence France‐Presse) —Nikolai V. Podgorny arrived here today from Rangoon for his official visit. The Soviet President and his eight‐member delegation from Moscow were greeted at Hanoi's Gialam Airport by North Vietnamese officials including Le Duan, first secretary of the Communist party. Premier Pham Van Dong and Defense Minister Vo Nguyen Giap.

headline: Enemy Shelling of Hamlet Makes the Voters Wary
lead_paragraph: ANDUOC, South Vietnam, Oct. 3—The Vietcong fired a mortar shell into this hamlet 22 miles northwest of Saigon a half hour before the polls opened this morning, and only an intrepid handful of villagers came early to cast their ballots for President Nguyen Van Thieu or to deposit them as a negative vote, into the wastebaskets provided In each curtained booth.

headline: Dictatorship in Saigon
lead_paragraph: The lopsided election results announced by the Saigon Government can give no comfort to Americans or for that matter to democratically inclined South Vietnamese. President Thieu's proclaimed 91.5 per cent mandate in one‐man vote is the kind of result that could be expected from the regime in Hanoi, to which Saigon was supposed to offer a democratic alternative.

headline: SAIGON RELIEF FORCE AT CAMBODIAN BASE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 (AP)—A tank‐led South Vietnamese rescue column fought its way through North Vietnamese lines this evening to relieve a besieged artillery base inside Cambodia, South Vietnamese spokesmen said.

headline: U. S. Aides Pleased
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters)—United States officials today reiterated their misgivings about South Vietnam's one‐man presidential election, but expressed satisfaction at the high voter turnout.

headline: Ellsberg Wins a Motion For Inventory of Property
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 (AP)—A motion for an independent inventory of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg's records and other property was granted to the defense today by a United States District Court judge, William M. Bryne Jr.

headline: Colonel's Mylai Report Is Called Untrue
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 4—The former commander of helicopter battalion flying in support of attacking infantrymen at Mylai 4 said today that a report he had read of the incident while In Vietnam “didn't tell the truth.”
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU SAYS VOTING SHOWS DEMOCRACY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4—President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his victory in the one‐man presidential election yesterday was a clear example of democracy in action.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times

headline: OBSERVER
lead_paragraph: “I received the impression that most people were unaware . . of ... an offer of secret talks by the N.L.F.”
author: By John Mendelson

headline: TALLY QUESTIONED IN DANANG VOTING
lead_paragraph: DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 4—High American officials, Buddhist opposition leaders and independent observers today sharply challenged the Government's claims of a heavy turnout of voters in Danang and Hue in yesterday's presidential election.
author: By Craig R. Whitney Special to The New York Times

headline: Medina Quitting Army, May Be Out in 2 Weeks
lead_paragraph: FORT McPHERSON, Ga. Oct. 4 (AP)—Capt. Ernest L. Medina, acquitted of murder charges in the Mylai assault of 1968, submitted his resignation to Third Army headquarters here today.

headline: PODGORNY GIVES PLEDGE IN HANOI
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Oct. 4—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union gave the Vietnamese Communists a strong pledge of continued support and assistance today in their war against the United States and other opposing forces in Indochina.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: Washington: For the Record
Article 1 ‐‐ No Title
lead_paragraph: TOKYO, Oct. 5 (AP)—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union completed two days of talks in Hanoi today, the North Vietnamese press agency reported.

headline: Habib Sworn In as Envoy
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) —Ambassador Philip Charles Habib, a diplomat with long experience in Asia's divided countries of Korea and Vietnam, was sworn in today as the new United States Ambassador to South Korea.

headline: 150 in Paris Assail U.S.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 5 — About 150 youths demonstrated in front of the United States Consulate tonight against United States policy in Vietnam.

headline: SAIGON'S FORCES SAID TO ROUT FOE
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 6 (AP)—A South Vietnamese general said yesterday that a badly battered North Vietnamese force was in retreat after 10 days of fighting along the Cambodian border northwest of here.

headline: Militant Students in Saigon Vow to Pursue Struggle
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5—The militant students here, bitter opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu and of the Americans, who support him, say they will continue their campaign against the President and his allies.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: Colonel's Defense Seeks to Tell Jury of Lie Tests
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 5—Defense attorneys for Col. Oran K. Henderson argued today that his court‐martial jury should be permitted to learn that the defendant voluntarily took a lie detector test at the request of the Government.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: HENDERSON GAINS A POINT AT TRIAL
lead_paragraph: FORT MEADE, Md., Oct. 6 —The military judge in the trial of Col. Oran K. Henderson ruled today that a key prosecution witness would not be permitted to make a courtroom identification of the defendant.
author: By Douglas Robinson Special to The New York Times

headline: Vietnamese Food Far From the Front Lines—North Carolina
lead_paragraph: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C.—Payday comes to Fort Bragg twice a month. Thirtynine thousand military personnel desert their 150,000‐acre base and head, by car, bus and thumb, along the plastic wasteland of Bragg Boulevard looking for fun.
author: By Raymond A. Sokolov Special to The New York Times

headline: SENATE APPROVES DEFENSE BILL, 82‐4
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6—The Senate passed today a $21‐billion military procurement bill containing a Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment and a provision permitting the importation of Rhodesian chrome in defiance of a United Nations embargo.
author: By John W. Finney Special to The New York Times

headline: Reds Let French Expert Work at Angkor
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 — A noted French archeologist is being permitted by the North Vietnamese to cross back and forth through Communist lines in Cambodia to continue his lifelong work of preserving the ruins of Angkor.
author: By Terence Smith Special to The New York Times

headline: HARRIS ADDRESSES DEMOCRATS HERE
lead_paragraph: Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma took his “new populism” campaign for the Democratic nomination for President to New York City and Connecticut yesterday.

headline: B‐52'S BOMB FOE NORTH OF SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Thursday, Oct. 7 (AP)—Three Iwaves of B‐52 bombers pounded enemy positions along the Cambodian border today in a second day of follow‐up raids after a week and a half of frontier fighting.

headline: A Saigon General Told a Lie To Boost His Troops' Morale
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 6 (AP)—Lieut. Gen Nguyen Van Minh, commander of the military region that includes Saigon, said today that he had “told a lie” to raise the morale of his troops during the recent fighting along the Cambodian border.

headline: FOES OF THIEU SEEK TO NULLIFY ELECTION
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct — Opponents of President Nguyen Van Thieu today filed a suit in the Supreme Court calling upon the justices to declare last Sunday's one‐man Presidential election unconstitutional and to nullify the results.

headline: The Colonel and the Army
lead_paragraph: After a delay of more than one year, Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke has agreed under Congressional pressure to review the disturbing case of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert. The career of this up‐from‐the‐ranks professional soldier with an outstanding combat and command record was shattered by a still unresolved conflict between him and his superior officers. At issue is whether Colonel Herbert's efforts, first to stop and then to report atrocities allegedly committed by. American and South Vietnamese military personnel led, as he maintains, to the reprisals against him.

headline: Students Burn Truck
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Thursday, Oct. 7 (Reuters) — Buddhist students burried a Government truck parked outside an American billet here today in violent protest over the re‐election of President Nguyen Van Thieu in Sunday's election.

headline: CLASH IN CAMBODIA REPORTED BY SAIGON
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Oct. 8 (AP)—The South Vietnamese command reported today a new flareup of fighting across the Cambodian border and said allied ground and air forces had killed 50 North Vietnamese soldiers without suffering any losses.

headline: U.S. Asks Reds at Paris Talks For Data on Dead Prisoners
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Oct. 7—William J. Porter, chief United States negotiator at the Vietnam peace talks here, today asked members of the Communist delegations for information about American prisoners known to be dead in Vietnam.
author: By Clyde H. Farnsworth Special to The New York Times

headline: Saigon Set to Announce Tough New Taxing Policies
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7—The Government today was reported planning to announce soon a series of economic reforms intended to strengthen the South Vietnamese economy and reduce its dependence on American aid.
author: By Iver Peterson Special to The New York Times

headline: MUSKIE CRITICIZES NIXON ON ‘DELAYS’
lead_paragraph: PATCHOGUE, L. I., Oct. 7—Senator Edmund S. Muskie criticized the. Nixon Administration tonight for what he termed the “politics of postponement” of solutions to problems of the economy, the environment and the war in Vietnam.
author: By David A. Andelman Special to The New York Times

headline: Advertising:
lead_paragraph: The Advertising Council and SSC&B have run into a major problem in their planned campaign on behalf of American prisoners of war in Southeast Asia. They can't get the copy cleared by the television networks.
author: By Philip H. Dougherty

headline: MOSCOW AND HANOI SIGN NEW AID PACTS
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, Oct. 7 (AP)—The Soviet Union has signed new military and economic aid agreements with North Vietnam, Tass announced tonight.

headline: U.S. Death Toll in War Is Put at 21 for Week
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, Oct. 7 (AP)—Twenty‐one Americans were killed in combat in IndoChina last week, eight fewer than the previous week, the United States command reported today.

headline: SOVIET‐HANOI TIES APPEAR BOLSTERED
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Oct. 8—President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union left Hanoi by air today, ending a five‐day visit that appears to have further consolidated Soviet‐North Vietnamese ties.

headline: Laird Voices Happiness
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) —Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird, voicing happiness over Sergeant Sexton's release, said today: “We remain concerned about the hundreds of other of our military personnel held” in Southeast Asia.

headline: FRESH ENEMY UNIT IN A BORDER CLASH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)—Fighting broke out again today along the Camobodian‐South Vietnamese border. South Vietnamese infantrymen clashed with North Vietnamese regulars near Route 22 just south of United States Fire Base Pace, the area where the Saigon troops engaged the enemy Thursday.

headline: Damaging File Dropped From Col. Herbert's Record
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 —The Army has thrown out a damaging efficiency report that was added to the file of Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert after he charged two fellow officers with covering up alleged atrocities by American troops in South Vietnam. The action, announced today by Secretary of the Army Robert F. Froehlke at the Pentagon, clears the way for Colonel Herbert to stay in the military. Had the Army not elected to clear the colonel's record of charges of having “no ambition, integrity, loyalty or will for selfimprovement” and of having “a terrible appearance,” he would have been forced to retire from military service effective March 1, 1972, Mr. Froehlke said. The efficiency report, a periodic evaluation of officers' performance, was filed by Col. J. Ross Franklin, who had been, accused by Colonel Herbert of, derelietion of duty by covering up the alleged atrocities.

headline: Vietcong Release G.I. Held for 2 Years
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 8 (AP)—United States sergeant listed as missing in action was released by the Vietcong today after more than two years' captivity. He walked barefoot for eight hours through jungles to safety and reported that he had seen other American prisoners during the two years.

headline: Wide Soviet‐Hanoi Accord Initiated by Podgorny Visit
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG, Sunday, Oct. 10—North Vietnam and the Soviet Union have set up a joint committee that will work out details of long‐term economic, trade, cultural, scientific and technological relations between the two countries.
author: By Tillman Durdin Special to The New York Times

headline: G.I. Freed by the Vietcong Lost 50 Pounds as P.O.W.
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 9 (AP)—S. Sgt. John C. Sexton Jr., released by the Vietcong after more than two years as a prisoner of war, lost 50 pounds during his captivity, a United States military spokesman said today.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: SAIGON — President Nguyen Van Thieu's real problems began last week after he solved one that has commanded priority for months over other affairs of war and state—how to hold an election that would ensure an overwhelming vote for his continuance in office.
author: —Craig R. Whitney

headline: Letters to the Editor
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: John F. Sterling Jr

headline: Saigon Reports a Breakthrough To Battered Base in Cambodia
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct 9 (AP)—A column of 1,200 South Vietnamese rangers, led by tanks, was reported to have fought through North Vietnamese lines today and reached a battered artillery base in eastern Cambodia.

headline: Letter
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
author: Roy C. Bates

headline: Vietminh Veterans Recall the War Against the French
lead_paragraph: TUYHOA, South Vietnam, Oct. 8—Many men of Phuyen province, famous for its guerrilla fighters in the, nine‐year war against the French, are silent now. Many do not even speak to their children of the war that they helped win.
author: By Gloria Emerson Special to The New York Times

headline: The Colonel's Vindication
lead_paragraph: Dismissal by the Army of a damaging efficiency report against Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert removes the threat of that officer's forced retirement from a lifetime of dedicated service. It should also clear the way for his return to the command positions and the promotion to which his previous combat performance entitled him.

headline: Colleen Pelleriti Wed to Captain
lead_paragraph: HOMESTEAD, Fla., Oct. 9 —Miss Colleen Mary Pelleriti was married here this afternoon to Capt. Carl P. Parlatore of the Air Force, who flew 230 combat missions in Vietnam as a jetfighter pilot. Msgr. George M. Claric performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in a military service in the chapel at Homestead Air Force Base, where the bridegroom is stationed.

headline: The World
lead_paragraph: In the next twelvemonth of twilight war in Indochina, the United States will have to make hard decisions about some of the; engines of destruction being plapeti, in the hands of South Vietnatn's military regime. headline: Screen: Stember's '7254':Forum Offers Diffuse Saga of Young Man
lead_paragraph: The Film Forum rates credit for lending a helping hand to another aspiring, if unsung, moviemaker, by giving theatrical exposure to John Stember's first film, "7254," which will run at that intimate showcase for generally noncommercial fare today through Sunday. But good deeds and intentions aside, Mr. Stember, who is a fashion photographer, gives us a good deal less than meets the eye or the ear in this ill-defined and disconnected saga of a modern young man's angst in a world rent by wars and other dissensions.Mr. Stember, who produced and directed from his story and for his own company, SHA Productions, apparently was uncertain about just how he would project the problems endured by his vaguely limned but highly distraught hero.What we're exposed to is a series of vignettes photographed in color against mostly local backgrounds that give the impression of having been tossed in merely to indicate progressive anxieties.The anxieties appear to have basis in awesome facts. We see televised scenes indicating Hitler's holocausts, and others, up to and including Vietnam. Vietnam is what appears to have set off our troubled pettish hero, Alan Midgette. In disjointed scenes, he is oddly unresponsive to the pleas of his nude, beautiful but callow wife (Phoebe McAdams) to come to bed; to his loquacious, divorced mother (Ruth Ford) and her saccharine adoration, and to a vague, older friend (Paul Gallan), who, at one point, chases him desperately as he rows down a sylvan stream.Unfortunately, Mr. Midgette, a lank-haired, slightly delicate blond type sporting a flowing white scarf, is given to long, moody silences and few words that convey coherency or depth. In a reflective sequence shot for no real reason on a windswept beach through waving weeds, his Vietnam observations include, "Those are real babies crying, this war is a crime against nature."The dialogue, done in an ad lib, Andy Warhol technique, is not a crime against nature but it does little to put the principals in sharp focus. Nor does it do much for the meaning of the climax, which has our tortured Alan fleeing inexplicably from everyone at an airport.The title, "7254," a program note says, is the "Kodak designation for color negative film." Well, it wasn't used especially positively this time.
author: By A. H. Weiler

headline: The L. B. J. Library: The Life and Times Of Lyndon Johnson in Eight Full Stories
lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex.—“It's all here with the bark off,” Lyndon Johnson told blue‐ribbon crowd at the dedica tion of the L.B.J. Library here last May, nodding back toward the $18‐ million structure and implying that therein reposed the real lowdown on himself and his much‐discussed “place in history.” Like much else about the former President, that proposition is debatable. Indeed, after ambling through the library's museum and viewing all sorts of exhibits ranging from letters to Johnson from Bobby Kennedy and the Smothers Brothers to a display that has “Hello Lyndon” issuing from hidden tape recorder, yet finding barely any mention of the war in Vietnam, began to suspect that quite a bit of bark was still in place.Standing at the bottom of the mag nificent travertine stairway leading from the ground (first) floor to the Great Hall (second floor), the visitor can see the outside rows of stacks behind five‐story glass wall. headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: Many Fruitless Peace Bids to Hanoi
lead_paragraph: IN the summer of 1965 I came to the painful conclusion that an independent South Vietnam could survive only if the United States and other nations went to its aid with their own fighting forces. From then until I left the Presidency, we had three principal goals: to insure that aggression did not succeed, to make it possible for the South Vietnamese to build their country and their future in their own way and to convince Hanoi that working out peaceful settlement was to the advantage of all concerned.

headline: The ‘Burden’ of the Constitution
lead_paragraph: The men at the executive levels of justice have trampled on traditions and ideals and principles: of justice. They see the Constitution as a burden, an ‘obstruction to he overcome, as technical barrier to be avoided when inconvenient, evaded where possible, and ignored if necessary. Pledged by oath to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution, instead they defile, dilute and debase it. Proclaiming that they will. strictly construe it, rather they constrict and destroy it Slowly, stealthily, they arrogate to themselves the powers that the Constitution meant to be shared ‘and’ powers that the Constitution never meant Govern ment to have at all.
author: By Edward M. Kennedy

headline: Rustic Utopia, doomed in advance
lead_paragraph: Old Man Ritter—a 77‐year‐old Vermonter, leathery, hard nosed, crotchety—has a reputa tion for eccentricity even among his fellow eccentrics. He also has apple orchards and a de caying farmhouse, untenanted. Enter Josh, a Vietnam veteran with long hair, painful memo ries and a dream of starting a commune. The two men meet and touch across the genera tions. “You a hippie?” Ritter asks. “There aren't any hip pies anymore,” Josh replies. Gears mesh, the relentless mills start to grind, and we're off on another inspection of the mori bund American dreams of agrarianism, Utopian socialism and the life.
author: By. James R. Frakes

headline: That wonderful emperor who gave you Pearl Harbor
lead_paragraph: H. A. L. Fisher once opened his memorable history of Europe with the affirmation that history was one emergency after another. Selected readings in recent years might sug gest that American‐Asian relations have been one damn conspiracy after another. The Pentagon Papers evoked Lyndon Johnson's conspiracy to wage war against North Vietnam; McCar thyism conjured up a conspiracy of pro‐Communist intellectuals and State Department officials losing China to the Chinese and/or Soviet Com munists; Pearl Harbor inspired a Roosevelt conspiracy to maneuver the nation into the European war through the back‐door of conflict with Japan; and Pearl Harbor also demonstrated a Japanese conspiracy to conquer Asia and dictate peace from the White House. With the publication of David Bergamini's “Japan's Imperial Conspiracy,” the history of modern Japan and the origins of the Pacific war have now been reduced to one grand conspiracy of the Japanese emperoro.
author: By James B. Crowley

headline: By Lyndon B. Johnson: The Tet Offensive
lead_paragraph: On March 31 1968 while sitting at my desk in the White House and facing the shiny eyes of the television cameras, I announced four major decisions. would not accept my party's nomina tion as candidate for another term. was stopping most; of the bombing of North Vietnam in the hope that would lead to peace. I had decided to make the expansion and modernization of South Vietnam's armed forces a goal of even higher priority. Finally, to meet existing needs, I had decided to make a small increase in the size of our own military forces in Vietnam.

headline: A shrug to the road ahead
lead_paragraph: A rapid survey of the sixties, competent, inclusive, brightly written—on the face of things, what could this be but good value?. The historian, a Rutgers professor, bends himself sen sibly at the start to demytholo gizing, praising Ike for talking rot and being resourceful, creaming Camelot for talking chic and being ineffective. He studies L.B.J. in triumph, the beginning of the desperate time in Vietnam, the emergence of the counter culture and the New Left. There's a chapter for the year of disasters, 1968 (Tet, the murders of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, the Chi cago convention), and another in defense of the author's con viction that the‐end of the dec ade really ended something (“Epilogue: The Revolution Is Over”). And there are frequent diversions from straight chron ological accounting: summaries of pop culture trends; evoca tions of the early days of the period's heroes and villains (Cesar Chavez, Ralph Nader); profiles of new institutions (Women's Lib, Hell's Angels).
author: By Benjamin Demott

headline: Reader's Report
lead_paragraph: If Richard Jessup was un kind to ultra‐militant youth in his last novel “A Quiet Voyage Home,” he is doubly mean to their elders in this one. All the bad rumors about America come true, and are laid right at the doorstep of the genera tion now phasing itself out, from moral corruption to police brutality. The present victim of society's evils is an 18‐year‐old youth, emptied of illusions by two‐years’ combat service in Vietnam. (He lied about his age to enlist.) Terry Foxway comes back from the war a tabula rasa, void of all excess psychological baggage except his pragmatic conditioning for survival. The good old U.S.A. has a fine opportunity to write some nice things into Terry's personality, but everyone plays him false: his girl, his teach ers, his employers, the VIP's who admire his war record. From his parents he learns only an oppressive sense of empti ness. (“It was as if they had misplaced their lives.”)

headline: Arts Abroad
lead_paragraph: STUTTGART—Sixteen ma jor West German theaters, although none in the East, are in the process of staging a new play by Peter Weiss. No other play by Weiss—a writer of partly Jewish de scent who holds a Swedish passport—has thus far had a triumph comparable to his “Marat/Sade,” even though his experimental prose has been immense ly influential here. His earlier plays —on Auschwitz, Vietnam and Portuguese colonialism—had merely been successes. His most recent play before the new one, “Trotsky in Exile,” was rather weak both as a documentary and as a drama. Now “Hölderlin,” whatever its qualities and shortcom ings, is truly a major event, a play about the poet Fried rich Hölderlin.

lead_paragraph: Mary McCarthy returned to her alma mater, Vassar, for the first time since 1963, when her novel “The Group” disturbed alumnae who felt they had been maligned in the book. While Miss McCarthy lectured at seminars' and took part in other Vassar centennial activities, it was clear that all was not forgiven by the school or by the author. Miss McCarthy, for example, said she had accepted the invitation to the centennial in “a moment of generosity.” She also said the writing courses She took at Vassar in the nineteenthirties had made her style “retrogress.” Vassar's attitude toward her seemed expressed on its bookshelves. While the college book store and library had displays of boblcs by alumnae authors, including some by Miss McCarthy, not a single copy of “The Group” was shown.
author: James F. Clarity

headline: Foreign Notes
lead_paragraph: Something New

headline: Vietcong Say They Used Bees to Rout U.S. Patrol
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (Reuters)—The Vietcong Radio reported that guerrillas had released a swarm of bees toward a United States patrol recently, forcing them to beat “panicky retreat.”

headline: 10 IN U.S. COPTER DIE IN NHATRANG CRASH
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 30 (AP)—The United States command reported today that a big Army helicopter had crashed at sea Tuesday near Nhatrang, 195 miles northeast of Saigon and that all 10 Americans aboard had been killed.

headline: Saigon, With Officer Problem, Says New Graduates Are Better
lead_paragraph: THUDUC, South Vietnam, Oct. 20—When Ding Cong Hai failed the entrance examination to Saigon University last year, he was drafted and ordered to report to the sprawling Vietnamese officer candidate school here. He graduates shortly and will become a combat platoon leader in the infantry, to serve for the duration of the war—and who knows what that is, he said.
author: By Fox Butterfield Special to The New York Times

headline: Delay on Calley Foreseen
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (UPI)—It may be next summer before the court‐martial conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. will be heard by the United States Army Court of Military Review, the chief Judge, Maj. Gen. Kenneth J. Hodson, said yesterday.

headline: OFFICIALS SEEKING STOPGAP PROGRAM FOR FOREIGN AID
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30—The Administration took steps today to assemble a stopgap foreign aid program from the wreckage of the permanent program in the wake of the Senate's 41‐to‐27 vote yesterday killing the $3.5‐billion authorization bill.
author: By Felix Belair Jr. Special to The New York Times

headline: Guardian of the Ruins at Angkor Walks Delicate Path Amid War
lead_paragraph: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Oct. 30 — Discouraged over the world's failure to respond actively to her pleas to prevail on the Vietnamese Communists to evacuate the temples of Angkor and allow the magnificent ruins to be neutralized, Cambodia watches uneasily, while the French curator of her national monument continues to cross into enemy‐held territory to carry on his work of preservation.
author: By Henry Hamm Special to The New York Times

headline: Proposals for Reform Likely to Gain
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 30—The Senate's unexpected rejection of the Nixon Administration's foreign aid authorization bill last night is likely to stimulate proposals for radically new approaches in United States assistance to other nations.
author: By James M. Naughton Special to The New York Times

headline: THIEU TAKES OATH FOR 2D TIME, URGES SELF‐SUFFICIENCY
lead_paragraph: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Oct. 31 — Amid tight security, President Nauyen Van Thieu took the oath of office this morning for his second four‐year term and promptly sought to prepare the South Vietnamese for the departure of American combat troops.
author: By Alvin Shuster Special to The New York Times
